>>56440955
The thing it does better than the G36 is not be a G36.

Really though, heat problems. The Bundeswehr in 1997 didn't think the rifles would be used they way they ended up being used.

The barrel and sights of the G36 aren't actually connected by metal. They're independently mounted to the plastic receiver. The thin barrel heats rapidly during sustained fire, which degrades accuracy. This is normal in all firearms.

In the G36, the barrel transfers this heat to the plastic body, when becomes less rigid and may cause a wandering zero. This is made worse by the sights and barrel being essentially independent of each other with no rigid connection between them.

Bundeswehr test showed that by increasing the temperature of the rifle by 30C (~85F), accuracy at 100m fell to 7%. The Bundeswehr wants to make 90% of shots at that distance.

When the story broke, the German Ministry of Defense didn't say that the Bundeswehr had a good rifle that made some design choices that, with hindsight, were sub-optimal. posts.name: Anonymous

>>56443274
I’m sorry but what you refer to as an “AR-18 clone” is actually a m1 carbine clone, a rifle invented almost 30 years prior. You see, the m1 carbine uses a short-stroke (or gas tappet as it was called at the time) system to operate a rotating bolt in a semi-automatic rifle. This rifle began development in 1938 at the Winchester Repeating Arms company at the request of the US ordnance department for a small, light rifle that can be used by support troops. David “carbine” Williams (inventor of the gas tappet) often gets all the credit for the invention of this rifle, but he was actually a pretty big detriment to the project as he often threw fits and refused to work if he didn’t get his way. We should give our thanks to the whole team that invented this weapon, and all of the derivatives that it resulted in! If you would like to know more about this great weapon the book series “War Baby!” by Larry L. Ruth is a great resource, although it is a little pricey.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56448092
Arguing over which rifle gets to be the "short stroke piston" true source is a headache in every thread it happens. The SVT-38 entered actual production in 1938, which means it predates the M1 Carbine. Regardless, the M1 Carbine's tappet gas system that the SCAR's gas system was inspired by has obvious differences from the "traditional short stroke piston design" that most people think of. The SVT-38 both came first and has a gas system more similar to the likes of modern short stroke systems like the G36, 416, Bren 2, and yes, the AR18.

I still hate the idea of everything being an "AR18 clone" or god forbid an "SVT38 clone" simply because of it being a short stroke gas system. We don't call every long stroke system an AK clone.

>The Battle of Triangle Hill, also known as Operation Showdown or the Shangganling Campaign (Chinese: 上甘岭战役; pinyin: Shànggānlǐng Zhànyì),[nb 3] was a protracted military engagement during the Korean War. The main combatants were two United Nations (UN) infantry divisions, with additional support from the United States Air Force, against elements of the Chinese People's Volunteer Army (PVA) 15th and 12th Corps.[nb 2] The battle was part of UN attempts to gain control of the "Iron Triangle" and took place from 14 October to 25 November 1952.
>The immediate UN objective was Triangle Hill, a forested ridge of high ground 2 kilometers (1.2 mi) north of Gimhwa-eup. The hill was occupied by the veterans of the PVA's 15th Corps. Over the course of nearly a month, substantial US and Republic of Korea Army (ROK) forces made repeated attempts to capture Triangle Hill and the adjacent Sniper Ridge. Despite clear superiority in artillery and aircraft, the escalating UN casualties resulted in the attack being halted after 42 days of fighting, with PVA forces regaining their original positions.
The US had planned to take Triangle Hill in 5 days yet still couldn't take that hill from the chinese after 42 days of constant airstrikes/artillery strikes and combined arms assaults:

You need to learn more about cats and howthey act.

1- You to have make yourself appear smaller and non-threatening.
Stuff like : Turn yourself sideways, so he sees your profile. make yourself smaller by kneeling down.
And into thenext point :
2- Eye contact. Don't look at the cat directly in the eyes without blinking. That'sa sign of agression. Same thing with teeth, don't smile,it looks like you're a preadator showing its fangs.
The MOST important advice is this : Cats show affection to another by blinking slowly or just closing their eyes, while right next to you.
This is how you tell a cat that you like him and trust him.
Closing your eyes next to another predator shows that you trust them not to attack you when is this position of weakness.

There's other advice that is obvious but still worth noting like, don't run towards a cat or chase after him. Same for sudden movements or sounds.

Approach a cat slowly, making yourself small and stop before you get to him, to let him approach you for the rest of the way.
The cat needs to come to you.
Do like a dog and let him sniff your hand the first time you approach a cat.

So to recap.
- Approach cat in non-thratening manner and not all the way.
- Sit down or kneel closeto him and let him come to you the rest of the way.
- Let him smell you and get used to you.
- Don't maintain eye contact when appraoching, look away to put him at ease. Closing your eyes slowly signals to the cat you like him.

And of course : read the body language.
Wagging the tail or ears pulled back might mean he's pissed or scared.
So learn to read the cat and learn what he likes / doesn't like.
Cats have personalities. They can be nice or they can be assholes.

Good luck with the kitty-cat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
RUSI released it's preliminary findings on what the Ukraine war says about modern conventional warfare a few weeks ago. It is based upon data from the Ukie General staff, which is not publicly available.
Link has executive summary & longer PDF:
https://rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/special-resources/preliminary-lessons-conventional-warfighting-russias-invasion-ukraine-february-july-2022
Discuss.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Summary of findings:

1) There is no sanctuary in modern war.Survivability depends on dispersing ammunitions stocks, command and control, maintenance areas and aircraft.

2) Modern war requires a significant stockpile of munitions. Despite ATGMs being prominent in popular understanding in how Kiev front was defeated states it was actually mostly down to 2 Ukie arty brigades. When the war started Ukraine had rough parity with Russia in artillery. Shortage of munitions however that by June Russia had a 10 to 1 advantage.

3) UAS & counter UAS are absolutely crucial at all levels and parts of warfare. These should be organic to units, and due to the fact 90% are destroyed, cheap and replaceable. EW is the most effective counter to UAS.

4)The force must fight for the right to precision. Precision is not only vastly more efficient in the effects it delivers but also allows the force to reduce its logistics tail and thereby makes it more survivable. Precision weapons, however, are scarce and can be defeated by EW. To enable kill chains to function at the speed of relevance, EW for attack, protection and direction finding is a critical element of modern combined arms operations. Sequencing fires to disrupt EW and create windows of opportunity for precision effects is critical.

5) ISTAR makes concealment near impossible. Forces should be dispersed so as not to be economical targets. Mobility to paramour to evade an enemies kill chain. Effort should be made to concentrate effects and avoid concentration of forces unless circumstances are favourable. Forces need to be able to assist each other beyond direct line of sight. Mobility crucial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>Logistics (ammo)
>Drones

Seems like this can all be applied to unconventional warfare pretty efficiently. Wondering if Doc Larsen will review this article at some point...

>>56456507
>some British guy
Liddell Hart, but these people were just representative proponents of an emerging new doctrine of mobile armoured combat, and the Germans came up with a more complete idea

>realised that tanks spread around don't really achieve much and just get ground down, you need to mass them in giant overwhelming formations
An oversimplification. Whenever any new weapon is introduced, it is usually held in small specialist units first, then only deployed en masse when there is sufficient numbers. For example, brass cannon was spread out much like tanks were, until a bright young artillery officer named Napoleon put them all together in a Grand Batterie and concentrated their fire. Sometimes the opposite happens - another Napoleon innovation was to split up the army into Corps which could fight independently or concentrate as needed. (Sound familiar? Dispersion.) Wellington took the opposite view; he dispersed his artillery into his manoeuvre brigades, allowing his Army to fight more flexibly on multiple fronts. What is important to note here is that both methods were effective, depending on the situation; and both methods have their pros and cons.

The Germany Army combined several innovations and tactical training that made up "blitzkrieg", not just "yknow, just mass tanks" (a fact which was lost on Russians.) However they lacked the logistical resources to really effect some parts such as mechanised infantry and logistics. Ironically it is the US Army that put "blitzkrieg" into proper practice in WW2.

>like with schwerpunkt, you concentrate everything you have on one point and breakthrough
Another good example of overly focusing on one "principle". The Russians believe wholeheartedly in the single "schwerpunkt"; NATO doctrine cautions that an attack at 1 point is easily anticipated and defeated at 1 point. Commanders must be flexible and prepare for attack and defence at multiple points, situationally.

Hence the stupidity of Bakhmut.

A fact well-known in NATO wargames but which was having difficulty being pushed through the old school of generals. The RUSI analysis suggests that a balance of both is needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56452837
...da fuq?

Anon, you decock 1911s by clearing the weapon and pulling the trigger. Not by pulling the trigger on a live round and trying to ease the hammer down. The pistol is not required to be idiot-proof against NDs, by intent or design, if you try the latter. Though sometimes the half cock notch will save you from your Darwin award.

There is practically no reason to uncock the hammer on a loaded chamber on a 1911 to begin with, it has a manual safety for storing & carrying it loaded. In fact you shouldn't even need to touch the hammer at all for general operation. Treating a single action 1911 like a double action decocker pistol is basically just pure derp.

The only semi-reasonable explanation I can think of is that you are talking about Wilson Combat's Beretta models. In which case, the decocker is purposely made so it does not fire the round. That's why it's a decocker and not a trigger.

>>56445495
Funnilly enough, tanks were viewed quite skeptically by the Germans prior to WW2. The Germans only made tanks to counter British and French ones and even then never seriously invested all that much in them.

Post-WW1 tank developmnet halted thanks to the Versailles treaty, but while the Nazi's illegally developed new tanks (classified as tractors to get around treaties) they still only makde a small number of them, as most German Generals envisioned WW2 playing out like WW1, as did the allies, ie primarily fought by Infantry. In fact a good number of the Tanks the Nazi's fielded were actually Czech when they annexed Czechoslovakia, as well as other countries they annexed.

The big change happened with the Battle of France, little known fact, the French had more tanks than the Germans did (they invested heavily in them to make up for manpower shortages) and were arguably better made (save for being light on firepower), not to mention the number of British tanks in France. But it was General Mannstein who came up with a plan of concentrating all the German armor into one group to punch through the French defenses. This worked leading to the Nazi's hyping up the role of German tanks and how superior they were and all that aryan supremacy nonsense.

Even then the Nazi's were the least mechanized army of the war (outside the Japanese and Chinese), but from this point on tanks became a central part of Nazi propaganda to make themselves look strong. It was also useful for disguising how manpower starved they were (can't see the shellshocked 16 year olds when they are inside the tanks). Meanwhile the Nazi's thought since Tanks won the Battle of France, surely they were key to winning the war overall (a seemingly impossible victory that was swift and sudden), hence they kept investing not just in tanks in general (including offensive tanks while they were on the defensive) but absurd wunderwaffe tanks like the Maus and Ratte.

posts.name: Anonymous

This is what happens when a ruler starts a war on a whim, without any public demand or support behind it. Sure, russians will technically speak in favor of it, when asked, and will even unenthusiastically fight, but almost none of them give a fuck about the results, and no one puts in any effort, which in turn discourages people from putting effort even more. It's a death spiral for motivation, hence the latest news about bringing clowns to the frontline in an attempt to lift soldiers' spirits, and russian claims of Ottawa sowing dissent among russian troops via social media.

Russian army ultimate collapse will not look like a panicked retreat on all fours back to Belgorod. It will be slow, inevitable rot, when systems stop working, orders stop being fulfilled, messages aren't received, and soldiers, while staying in their positions, are demoralized to the point of folding like wet paper at the slightest push from the enemy. But there's still a long-ish road to this terminal stage.

We already know the Russians finally got the clue by dispersing their ammo dumps now that there's fewer large scale detonations. The underlying problem is that Russian logistics is still extremely dependent on rail networks, so dispersing their supplies means moving them farther away from the rail hubs, making it more difficult to transport them to front.

It also doesn't help that Russia has a terrible truck system. They don't have the drivers, trucks, or organization to be able to reliably truck everything they need to the front 24/7.

It is always tea first then milk. The reason milk was put first was because in ye olde times, when you put hot tea into a cup (usually fine China) it would break under the sudden temperature change. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56456823
>VHF radios are line of sight
Kinda but not really.

>and therefore limited to a practical max range of about 4km
Eh. The rule of thumb for handhelds is 1W = 1mi, so even if they're using little 5W handhelds they're still probably going to double that in a vacuum (say, just trundling along a road in formation) for handheld-to-handheld comms. If they're radioing back to a base or something where there's a proper transceiver and antenna then they're much easier to hear, especially if you can increase your altitude and get away from potential obstructions. Also worth noting is that most backpack and vehicle-mounted VHF units are going to be capable of of 30-50+W with better antennas and I would be surprised if they weren't using HF, especially since NVIS is so handy.

>So you need repeaters to communicate farther, such as to units above company level or artillery.
If all you have is a handheld it certainly helps.

posts.com:
>>56457397
>I was also thinking, maybe , with repeaters, radios can use less powerful signals making radio stations harder to detect?
That's not really what repeaters are for. Repeaters are for when your radio isn't powerful enough to get your signal to where it needs to go; if the repeater is close enough that you can use less than the maximum wattage but want to avoid being detected then it's pretty obvious that you're very close to the repeater - which, as its entire point is to blast a signal farther than you can, is generally less than stealthy. For sneaky breeki stuff many handhelds can go all the way down to 0.25W or less so that something sniffing for radio traffic on your frequencies isn't going to pick you up unless you break radio silence at very close range.

>And also they work as decoys? With enemy not knowing if the source of signal is a command center or just a single repeater station, thus if they have more potential targets, and survivability of units is higher thanks to that?
Not really, no. Repeaters are definitely a juicy target though because destroying one can severely impair enemy coordination and information sharing - especially if they're also doing something like routing traffic. Imagine the black circle in pic rel is the repeater's range, red is Lt. Sasha, Blue is Sgt. Alexi and green is Sgt. Ivan. With the repeater up, only Sasha is in TX range of the repeater but the repeater is more powerful and will send it back out to both Alexi and Ivan. Sasha and Alexi can talk to each other without the repeater because they're within range of each other, but they can't reach Sgt. Ivan and Sgt. Ivan can't reach them. If Lt. Sasha gets a call on the satphone telling him that there are BMPs moving to flank Sgt. Ivan and that Sgt. Ivan needs to get out of there, he needs the repeater to pass that along and if the repeater is down then Sgt Ivan is on his own.

posts.com:
>>56454864
>out of all the videos there's not 1 instance where it worked
There's probably a little bit of selection bias. Fewer people are going to upload videos where their hit fails to cause significant harm to the tank. Besides that, it kind of depends on ERA, some ERA, like Kontakt I, the bricks, are vintage like early 1980's stuff, so they will have very limited effectivenss against munitions that are designed to counter them. Secondly, I think we have to consider how effective they are compared to having nothing extra at all. Even if they will provide little protection against more modern munitions or only provide protection for one or two hits, that's still better than just having '70's vintage composite armor of a T-72 or T-64. A lot of munitions available to both Russia or Ukraine are older munitions that ERA may be more able to counter; I think this especially works in favor of Ukrainian tanks with ERA as the Russians have fewer Western AT munitions. Thirdly, cope squares aren't necessarily useless. It's pretty common for militaries to allow troops to have things that may not provide much tangible benefit, but which might make crews or ground troops feel safer and therefore have a higher morale (e.g. tankers in WWII putting sandbags or tracks on their tanks).

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56453825
I adore the MG42/MG3 family aesthetically and as an efficient piece of industrial design. It is a fantastic, simple, lightweight and well proven GPMG with a lot of things going for it on paper.

In practice it is still one of the best MGs out there, but it is a cheap design made of sheet metal that has a limited lifespan. Like many MGs, as it approaches it's end of life reliability problems gradually become more frequent and severe with receiver stretching ultimately rendering any given example non-functional and non-repairable at some point.

As a counter, the FN MAG is a much heavier and more expensive design but it is truly built like an anvil. The MAG can last an absolutely stupendous amount of time and rounds fired, with a steady supply of replacement barrels and small parts one example can be kept running pretty much forever. This translates to significant cost savings over time from being able to refurbish old machine guns instead of fully replacing them, and also carries over as extremely good dependability in the field and confidence that the men carrying it ultimately have.

Which is better?
Well if you're going to fight a big nasty war of attrition and are expecting heavy losses the MG3 is better because it's cheaper and lighter. In that situation the MG3 would probably be lost or destroyed before it has a chance to fire enough to wear out and you can get more of them in the hands of more crews.
If it's a primarily a peacetime army that's going to train a lot and reuse weapons in a lot of small police actions, the MAG is more dependable and has a far longer maximum service life which more than makes up for the added cost. Not much you can do about weight, but it doesn't matter when mounted on a vehicle or in a fixed position.

posts.com:
I really want everybody here to reflect on this. This guy has been doing this since at least 2019, so we are talking about 3 years of near-daily effort to get attention from strangers on the internet. In the same timeframe, there were other people who built their own houses, saved up for their dream car, or started a relationship and had their firstborn child. These objectives that took just as long yielded incredible benefit from the hard work it takes to accomplish them. Yet here we are with this terminal NEET, who is peaking right now as he sits in the same office chair in the same room staring at the same screen of the same anime forum. He is over the moon because what looks to be <10 people have been talking about him for one morning. This ephemeral state will no doubt fade away by tomorrow, and he will keep chasing it by shitposting more and more and more. Meanwhile, that person with the new house will renovate it and start a family there, the person with their dream car will drive it on a dream vacation, and that person with their new child will raise their child and secure a legacy. In another three years, he will still be here chasing another moment where people talk about him on the same anime forum and nothing to show for it.

Writing that reflection saddens me thinking that this is the state of some young men. The ones that don't flip out and shoot up a school end up wasting away long before they become geriatric. One chance at life and it's thrown away in a digital black hole. Once this website goes down and the archives disappear, there will be no proof that this guy even lived through the 10's and 20's. Alzheimer's would be a blessing, should this guy ever become sentient.

In a kierkegaard-ian sense, you have the capacity to regret any decision you make with enough thought about any other possible circumstance you could be in within the sea of life-possibilities. In a simpler sense, FOMO is a mental disease. And we rarely consider the downsides that would come along with every ideal scenario we fantasize ourselves living out: New houses become outdated/stale/subject to market fluctuations and disaster scenarios, Dream cars are the same but even worse, Relationships and Marriage have the almost certain ideation of separation/divorce, You could have a problem child that makes your life hell for 18 years, or brings embarrassment to your name, or comes out retarded and now you have a lifelong liability on your hands.
There's no ideal way to live life, we don't have enough control over it to reasonably expect optimal standards to be met. We should only do what we want to be doing, perhaps something that brings innate enjoyment/intrigue, and to actually live.
The only one who could live to be a failure is one who hasn't lived at all, or even tried to achieve what they truly want. Which is the one true thing that is in your control.

The main issue with the AR/M4 safety is how small it is. When it gets covered in ice, it's too small to get enough leverage on to overcome the ice. That's why the AK safety is easier to move by comparison when it gets frozen. It has a wider surface area that you can put much more force on and overcome the ice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56447444
There's a lot more shit getting frozen and seizing up on the AR though. The lever is the least of your worries. Even when they're able to move it to fire, the gun won't fire. If it manages to, the BCG gets stuck back in the buffer tube and there's no way to push it forward.the forward assist doesn't reach it back there, and you can't even open the gun when it's stuck back there because it sits between the two halves not allowing them to separate. You can try loosing it with a mortar, but your stock is plastic and might shatter, and if you bend the buffer tube the BCG is just going to permanently get stuck in there.

These are unforeseen flaws because the US never thought to test a military rifle candidate in extreme cold. The upper and lower not separating during certain malfunctions is a primary reason I don't trust ARs. Look up a "brass over bolt" malfunction and know how to clear it if you run an AR, knowing that could save your life. You have to keep pliers in your kit if you run an AR, you must have them on you if you're using that rifle for defense. What they wont show you in those clearance drills is that irl it gets jammed up there so bad the case bends and seizes it up, and you'll need pliers to grip the casing and rip it out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56446986
Flash freezing water inside the mag is a problem at these temps. Also condensation (multiple trips in and out without allowing the rifle to dry).
On ARs it's either the selector or mag drag slowing the bcg down. Usually once the bcg warms up, they start to run. Below -20 they struggle regardless.
On this thing, if your dumping water on it, it's either the selector or mag release. FAL barrel style selector so you can just beat it with a mag or something if necessary. Runs fine otherwise, even after dumping water on it, as long as it doesn't travel into the magazine and slow down feeding too much (bolt out runs the mag). I tried the water test and it flash froze about an 1/8" thick over the entire gun in about 5 seconds.
Lube choice is also an issue. Coom lube turns to molasses at -40. Grease becomes 2 part epoxy that's sat for a week. G96 does not.

>>56447805
>the BCG gets stuck
Ultimately, GT's ice tests aren't particularly realistic tests anyway. Has anyone ever dropped their rifle in a pool of water, fished it out and then left it to freeze? I would imagine not. If an AR gets a significant amount of moisture in it when you're out in the field during cold weather, you should shake/wipe it out as much as possible at the earliest convenience.

I live in New England, and winters can get absolutely frigid here. What I've done to keep my ARs running in below-freezing temps is to use a small amount of Break Free CLP on the BCG. Some people use thicker lubes that freeze up in cold temps, and that causes malfunctions. Break Free has never frozen up on me, but it's crucial to not use too much. Project Farm has a video that showed the results of putting various gun lubes in a freezer, and many of them did not fare well at all:

https://youtu.be/fibRewlndLg?t=683

>Look up a "brass over bolt" malfunction and know how to clear it if you run an AR
Aaron Cowan has a good video on common AR malfunctions and how to clear them, and covers brass-over-bolt starting at 12:45:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dB3q2Pj-6q8

I mean, I prefer ARs to AKs by a significant margin, and I don't care which platform people want to fanboy for. They both have pros and cons. Frankly, despite living in an area of a country known for very cold winters with a lot of snow, I'd be much more likely to encounter muddy conditions crawling around in some sort of SHTF situation, rather than going for an impromptu swim in the middle of winter. If it's so cold that water on my gun is likely to freeze very quickly, all bodies of water will already be frozen over anyway.

I'd far more concerned with condensation collecting on my AR during winter, going from cold to warm areas and vice versa, because that's how you end up with a rust/corrosion problem. That's why guys will leave their rifles out in the cold rather than bring them into a warm area after being out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56431918
I have an M96. Frankly it's the same as any Mauser, check the quality check for matching. Swedes were autistic about markings so almost every part is numbered, and most guns will have all important parts match at the least, total matching also not uncommon. There's so much less to worry about on Swedish guns because they saw no war except some going to Finland to have a little fun, and it is incredibly easy to find them in immaculate condition. I mean, the fucking Swedes are the only people autistic enough to tell Germany, "No, you don't do it good enough so we want to make our own Mausers. Also use our steel for those sample guns you're making us, because it's better." And be right on both counts. They have the stock disks which were used by armories to record the barrel quality, you can see if your gun was rebarrelled there. Bear in mind the information stamped on the stock is literally decades out of date, so trying to guess the current quality off of that is silly.

Personally, I would go for the M38, it's a very cool rifle at a more reasonable size than the M96. I also really like the m1894 carbines, a lot of them were made pre-1899, and therefore not legally a modern firearm so you can have it shipped to your door no background check no FFL without a C&R, which is pretty fucking neato. The M/94 was so far ahead of its time. ~18" barrel, 6.5 caliber rifle in 1894. It's over a hundred years later and people are finally rediscovering how great that is with AR10s and the like.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56432027
thanks alot for the info anon. If you are looking for an FN Model 50 i can only give you a bit of info, not much out there on these rifles. In the 50s FN made a contract with Colombia, since columbia got a ton of 30-06 surplus from the good ol USA for a good price. They made their last military mausers: The FN Model 50 in 30-06. They have a longer magazine and action and a cutout in the Receiver to accomodate longer 30-06 loads. They also made the stripper clip groove wider, i think for Springfield clips originally. They also send some of these Rifles to the congo, and kept some for their own army in reserve. The Colombian ones got the colombian crest on the receiver, the belgian ones the crown and the kings name in short. The colombians also converted some old 1924 Rifles to 30-06, those will have a "30" behind the stripper clip groove. A lot of the belgian ones will have the crown and other markings scrubbed off like mine. Also they made these with a grey-green type of coating for the colombian navy and the congo and black paint for the colombian and belgian army. They made two types: The shorter 1930 pattern and the longer 1924 pattern, mine is a 1924 pattern with a straight bolt handle and 23 inch barrel. They should take K98, VZ24 and Preduzece and FN bayonets. One very characteristic thing is a special buttplate with a wave pattern for more grip. Generally the "Congo" models saw alot of action and are worn accordingly, the belgian and colombian army ones are normally in great condition. Again, FN made these long after the war with the best materials and 30 years of experience, they are great shooters. Oh also, some (like mine) were refurbished before being sold to the civilian market, mine has a non matching stock in a great color and with FN Arsenal markings, thats normal as well. Also also, some have a 2000 meter rear sight, some have a 1900. Not sure whats up with that, i think they reused old parts for the rear sight

OP here. Frankly the thing about 6.5 Swedes is they realized, they don't need to fire artillery shells out of their rifles, because they shoot further and faster than is required for most engagements. 6.5 55 only has about 6-7lb of recoil, which is very forgiving; when they introduced the cartridge a increase in accuracy for their troops was pretty obvious from the start, because it's easier to have troops that are confident with their caliber and control the recoil easier. As other anon said, they are only now deciding to use 6.5 in military rifles, which wasn't something they just "realized" everybody just choose to be retards and use artillery shells instead.

I found my M96 in a pawn shop, all the parts match, and it's in practically factory condition besides minor rust spots that I've since steel wooled off, the bluing on the steel is some of the best quality I've seen from this period, I mean seriously the bluing looks better than some of the newer rifles I have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56458014
>it doesn't make the gun more accurate >means they're useless

Let's take some slavshit PSO optic as an example here. As other anons have already said, target identification is many times easier with a magnified optic than the naked eye. A PSO optic also comes with a rangfinder for both standing and prone targets, which makes determining the range of a target simple. You place the target between the two lines. That's it. So now you want to take your shot. That thin chevron is a much smaller focal point to focus on, rather than the wide, flat top of a front sight post. At distances greater than 200+ meters, your front sight post is going to look wider than the target and trying to place that in its center is simply going to take more effort, and more time. You have to continually move your focus between the front sight post and your target to ensure a good shot can be made, all while keeping sight allignment and sight picture. Once you find the focal point in an optic it's the only one you have to be made. These, when paired together, are all fantastic net positives for a bit of extra weight.

Other optics like the ACOG have features like a bullet drop indicator, making shot placement require less effort.

Nobody, at all, ever, once in this thread, tried to tell you that they make objects bigger. We know it is the APPEARENCE of the object that is bigger. Work on your reading comprehension and lurk more. I genuinely don't believe you have a single firearm to your name.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dropping some SocBloc classics:
Liberation - a soviet epic about later stage of WWII, featuring lots of massive scenes of armoured warfare (amount of tanks used for filming could be used to arm an african country), one of the first media mentions of July 20 conspiracy (together with Night of the Generals), and certain inaccuracies/lousy mockup tanks typical for 60s movies
Only old men are going to battle - a slice of life movie about soviet fighter pilots, mostly about their daily interactions than warfare.Still it's a cult classic
Battle of Neretva - another large epic, this time, yugoslav.
Un Comisar Accusa - romanian crime drama,set in pre-WWII Romania, inspired by the political cleansings organised by Iron Guard. Low budget, medium effort, aesthetic.
Four Tankmen and a Dog, Stakes are Higher than Life - two cult polish B&W TV series, one is about a tank crew, another is a spy movie.
Generation, Kanal, Ashes and Diamonds - a polish resistance trilogy by Andrzej Waida. I personally liked Ashes and Diamonds, because it has something in common with French New Wave (or I just like to think that way).
Vlad Tepes - the only somewhat true biopic about Dracula, surprisingly good.
Jan Hus, Jan Zizka and Against All - czech trilogy about hussite wars (since swords, flails and billhooks are /k/). The suits are colorful, the armour is somewhat realistic (On scale between '44 Henry V and Braveheart, this is closer to Henry V).
Krzyzacy - polish adaptation of novel by Henryk Sienkiewicz (for poles he's basically their own Walter Scott and Alexander Dumas, yet western audience prefers Quo vadis? for obvious reason). Less realistic than czech movies about hussites, teutons act like nazis, some of lithuanians look like cavemen. Still a nice watch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56442622
Some additions:
1949 Zvezda - just as 2000s remake, it's dedicated to the work of front recons, the guys who used to sneak behind german lines on foot, recover intelligence as well as valuable prisoners and sneak out. However, this movie is both more authentic and archaic than the remake.
1932 Sniper - probably the first movie that centers around sniper work. While using a fantastic premise for the story (main hero is a soldier in Russian Expedition Corps in France who's recieving sniper training - there were no trained russian snipers during WWI), the movie is filmed with Hesketh Hesketh-Prichard's "Sniping in France" in mind (translated in USSR for military and NKVD training purposes in 1920s), adapting few elements from it.
One Chance out of Thousand - a 1969 movie about specops mission going wrong and improvisation saving them from complete failure, produced by Andrei Tarkovsky (yes, the Solaris and Stalker Tarkovsky). Somewhat similar in spirit to movies like Guns of Navarone or Dirty Dozen.
Otyrad Osobogo Naznacheniya - there are two films under this name, both are totally unrelated. One, made in 1978, is a low budget action movie about special squad assigned to destroy a Katyusha lost during retreat to prevent germans from capturing it. Another was filmed during Perestroika (so the film is of even lower quality, making it difficult to watch), and this is an adaptation of Dmitry Medvedev's (no, not Iron Dimon, another one) book about his experience as a commander of partisan regiment near Rovno (capital of Reichskomissariat Ukraine), including actions of Nikolai Kuznetsov (the spy who managed to blend in with the germans as an officer and carried out executions of several high ranking men), activity of UPA and Taras Borovets.
Duma of Kovpake - short series about another soviet partisan commander, Sydir Kovpak - a WWI veteran who used to be a kolhoz chairman between wars and after that took part in partisan movement.

Age of Mercy - crime drama about post-war Moscow Criminal Police, hunting the elusive gang of robbers and assassins. Features some examples of great soviet actors at work, most notably, Vysotsky and Jigarkhanyan (John Silver's voice in Treasure Island)

Tali-Ihantala is very uneven movie varying from good scenes to basically ruined ones. The director suffered major health problems and the whole production faced serious financial issues, so the post-production was apparently kind of mess.

I cannot believe that nobody has yet mentioned Talvisota (Winter War) from year 1989. IMO it is a better war movie than any of the three filmed versions of Unknown Soldier. The story is realistic and gritty - being based on war experiences gathered from veterans of single infantry regiment. There was a remastered 4K Blue Ray version of the movie published recently and it has English captions. In addition there is also old extended miniseries (of five episodes) version of the movie, which is shown in Finnish tv every now and then.

Start at your school and describe the problem, tell them you're concerned where he picked this fear up and that you suspect it's from his interaction with other children or someone at the school because you can't identify another source. Small lies here can get you free help that the school district is already paid to provide.

Get a professional to talk with your son and try to determine the source. After that question is resolved, then you can figure out how to address it.

Listen to me carefully here, because I am Someone Who Knows The Fuck Out Of These Things: parents who don't know what they're doing will put far more fuck in their childrens' heads than almost anything they will encounter. You have a trust relationship with your child that will screw their head inside out if you get one word out of place.

For the sake of any cats or other pets involved, DO NOT bring a cat or kitten into the house until you get some sort of an evaluation from a specialist in childhood behavior. You are in over your head, get help. Get professional help.

PERIOD.

Incorrect. There is no teaching a dog basic friend or foe concepts. They either have it or they don't. Either their instincts are trustworthy enough, or they will never have it and then act accordingly. There is like...3 to 5 breeds where they're smart enough to figure these things out on a case-by-case basis, but once they decide HUSKY = BAD it is almost hopeless to try to unteach that, then you have to avoid all huskies.

Hello everyone!

I figure that buying a marauder with a decent scope will allow me to fill a role with what would otherwise would only be able to be filled by a takedown or an SBR. Pistols (firearms) wouldn't fill the role either as semi auto .22lr pistols are illegal to hunt with in this state despite semi auto .22lr rifles being totally fine. Bring a Marauder in a small hard (or well padded) case and if no foxes turn up while I'm lugging around my .223, I can at least take it out to shoot some squirrels or maybe even groundhogs. Solves a problem I have, choosing what to take on a specific day. I can take a semi auto .22lr rifle as well as a .223 for fox, but it's hell on the back having to also bring all my other junk, including a little take-down seat if it's wet and cold out.

>>56416316

PCP soon; I just wish there were more reviews on budget pumps for the tanks. Everyone ignores those, and it's a little concerning considering I have to rely on them to fill it.

I've posted this little guy before, but this is my first gun pic with him. He usually doesn't sit still long enough for one of these.
If anyone recognizes him, I have a little update on his health situation. He's got FIP, basically kitty covid. Lymph nodes swollen, liver swollen to double it's normal size, jaundiced, etc. We have him on some experimental treatment, isn't FDA approved yet. Seems to be working so far, he's regained normal color in his nose and the other cat isn't treating him like he's sick anymore. Lymph nodes going down too. This was just after the first shot of the stuff, the treatment is supposed to take a few months to clear all this up. He doesn't like needles as we've found, so we've ordered some pills of the same stuff that can be broken up in his soft food. Those come in tomorrow.
He hasn't really changed in his normal behaviors, so I think he's gonna pull through. This treatment has like an 80% to near 100% success rate, percentage of failure just means it won't work. This should work though since he's reacting to it.

ethyl 2-cyanoacrylate is not the same as 2-octyl cyanoacrylate. Medical glues are specifically compounded with esters that reduce their toxicity and increase their flexibility. posts.sub: Testing of 7th Turkish USV underway | Can Greece, Egypt challenge Turkey's East Med dominance?
posts.com:
Mersin-based defence company Kayacı Defence Systems prepares Turkiye’s seventh unmanned surface vessel. The company’s unmanned system was spotted today at Mersin Port.

Turkiye's other Armed Unmanned Surface Vessels (AUSV) include:
–ULAQ by Ares Shipyard and Meteksan Defence
–Sancar by Yonca-Onuk Shipyard and Havelsan
–Salvo by Dearsan Shipyard
–Albatros-S by Aselsan
–Mir by Sefine Shipyard and Aselsan
–Marlin by Sefine Shipyard and Aselsan
As there is no standard classification for maritime surface vehicles, Kayacı calls its product an “Unmanned Naval Vehicle.”

According to the Kayacı website, the unmanned system will be equipped with Automatic Radar Plotting Aid (ARPA) route line preservation system integrated into its radar. It will calculate the closest approaching point and the time of the closest point of approaching to cruise along its predefined route autonomously. The vehicle will be equipped with LIDAR, a thermal camera, night vision camera. Its endurance will be 48 hours at cruise speed. There is no information yet about whether it will be armed.

According to its website, the Kayacı company is focused on naval systems, avionics, naval electronics, unmanned vehicles, radar systems, and radar hardware/software solutions.

> https://turdef.com/Article/turkiye-has-a-new-unmanned-surface-vehicle/2551

Maybe. You can get tinnitus from living life, though, it’s not just from shooting. You can get it from a rock concert, or working with power tools. You can get it from headphones while gaming. You can get it from an ear infection. You can get it from a hairdryer. You can get it from the ocean while surfing. You can get it from high blood pressure. You can get it from driving for extended periods of time.

Just be smart, double up ear pro every time, shoot at outdoor ranges instead of indoor ones (both for noise and lead exposure reasons), and you’ll be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56452047

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No such thing as too much earpro. Decibels use a logarithmic scale, and the actual intensity of the sound doesn't directly correspond with perceived loudness. A 10dB increase represents 10x the intensity but only double the perceived volume. 20 dB is 100x the intensity and so on and so forth.

Unsuppressed firearms can hit sound pressure levels of 150-160 dB easily. Sounds over 140 dB will cause immediate pain and damage. 100-115 dB can cause hearing loss with as little as 5 minutes of exposure. Hearing damage is permanent and cumulative. Protect your ears.

https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/hearing_loss/what_noises_cause_hearing_loss.html
https://www.silencercentral.com/blog/how-loud-is-a-gunshot-gun-db-levels-compared/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56396143
that IFAK price is kinda optimistic nowadays. a real poorfag IFAK that will perform close to what is in this pic would be:
>2x cravat, $4, works as a TQ but not as effective as a commercial tourniquet
>4x kurlex gauze rolls, $5-10 (combat gauze is unnecessary, 75th ranger btn. did a study on this and no noticeable difference between hemostatic and regular gauze was found)
>2x ace wraps $3-7 iirc
>plastic baggie or two + some duct tape $1, works as a chest seal and is what 90% of EMTs use even in the states (throw a gauze pad into the baggie for wiping blood and dirt off the injury before applying the plastic bag - adds $2)
>medical shears $5-15, depending on brand
>roll of medical tape for smaller cuts etc
--------additional investement--------
2x CAT7 tourniquet. these are super important but go for $30+ a pop nowadays so not too poorfag friendly. you can snag two for $50 sometimes.
>compressed gauze from NAR or H&H (less bulk than kurlex rolls, but essentially the same thing - about $5 a pop)

shit like NPAs and decomp needles are a meme and never utilized by anyone in real life. TCCC doesnt even teach NPA application anymore, they favor the recovery position. decomps are often applied incorrectly even by paramedics and will kill people if done wrong + they very, very rarely make a difference.

Advice? Make sure it's fitted right so it doesn't rub. Plan for how you'll manage water, my rig has two standard canteens and space for two water bladders if needed. Generally, manage straps, zippers and dangling crap.
Probably the biggest issue is carrying sleeping gear. LBE can hold something like a hammock, tarp and polyethylene easily but tents and sleeping bags are not as easy. It depends on where and how you are sleeping.
My understanding is that in most long range patrol, which hunting in LBE is closest to, soldiers used poncho + light sleeping bag at most for sleeping, maybe in Vietnam carry a half bivouac. Depends on how dirty you want to get.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Speaking of comms anyone into GMRS radio?
The lioscense is good for 10 years, doesn't require a test and your immediate family can legally transmit over GMRS using your call sign.
I know some people think they're going to make contact with strangers on HAM radio when the SHTF and save the day but the reality is you need to communicate with your people and GMRS is simple. Chances are you're the only one in your family that's into this shit and you can hand anyone a GMRS radio and show them how to use it in 5 minutes.
They can also communicate with shitty FRS "walkie talkies" on the lower channels if that's all your friend's/family have but you should buy two radios minimum because us poorfags are probably going to have to provide comms for our poorfag family/friends.
The UV-5G can be used as a scanner, listen to HAM bands, get NOAA weather alerts, FM commercial radio, communicate with GMRS repeaters and it looks exactly like a UV-5R for that maximum operator LARP look and takes UV-5R accessories.
>UV-5G
>External speaker mic with audio jack output
>Noise canceling earpro with audio input
Poor fags comms setup.
Alternatively you can "jail break" a UV-5R HAM radio to illegally transmit on GMRS so you can communicate with "walkie talkies".

>>56444893
Even when you replace most of the shit anons here recommend, keep it as a backup. Can't tell you how many times I've run an old optic or light on a new build until the exact model I wanted comes in. Overall pretty well done when you consider your peripherals (7 mags is just enough for your rifle). Set aside a 15 & 33 round Glock mag and keep them 'bnib', or at most, put a box of ammo thru each so you know they're reliable with your gun (granted I've never had OEM Glock mags come from the factory that aren't). Shoot and train with the rest, but it's always good to have at least a couple guaranteed fresh crispy mags around (for example if you find yourself troubleshooting feeding, slide lock or BHO issues one day you have a 'control').

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56451273
If it really is you nerfanon, much respect. I'll mostly lurk and bump when it gets low in the catalog. But what I can try and share right now is mindset. IMO there's poorfag and then there's why-even-bother
>Off-brand optics/electronics
>Floppy cordura with bad stitching
>3rd party magazines (esp pistol)
Saving up for a Trijicon or a Surefire might be unrealistic, but Holosun and Olight shouldn't be (pls at least try for streamlight). Most options below that standard of quality will cost you more than it's worth in the long run, whether it underperforms or just outright breaks (hopefully not when you really need it).

Here's a humble pic from a few years back before I parted out my 10.5" PSA upper (which was probably a mistake). Kept the Holosun bc she's treated me right for at least 6 years. Other gear has held up great over the years...some wasn't as cheap as I'd like but I saved by not having to re-purchase or warranty anything. If gear is too low quality or doesn't fit into the long-term goals/training you envision, that's when I ask myself 'why even bother,' probably better to just save

>>56445121
The Bushnell is a lower priority than your lights since you have BUIS (always smart).
The lights should be addressed because respectively:
>Rifle/primary needs a capable and most of all reliable solution. Early on I standardized my rifle and handgun lights, ran Streamlight TLR 1 HLs on both (you can even get rifle kits with pressure pads for the TLR 1). Until then, I ran and highly recommend a Magpul light mount (picrel, can run any flashlight that'll fit in the rings). Look for something shock and waterproof with at least 500-800, ideally 1k+ lumens. Pressure pad should not be a determining factor over reliability and performance
https://magpul.com/rail-light-mount.html?mp_global_color=118
>Handgun light will also matter for the above stated reasons, and off-brand lights make finding a good compatible holster difficult and/or expensive

>>56455215
It really doesn't get better than this for carrier borne fighters. jack of all trades: the plane. Strong offensive capability, dogfighter, insane range (kept the top spot for this entirety of the war), great climb, heavy armament for an otherwise light as a feather plane. The Mitsubishi A6M Type 0 is a plane with true soul. The engineers toiled on this one like it was their own child, finetuning it, optimizing it, planning and re-planning, thinking out of the box to make it what it was, it was the offspring of a lot of blood and sweat, and it really shows.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Japanese war planners were completely aware that the Empire was lost. The strategy they took to retain some relevance as a global player was to drive a wedge between the grand coalition of the Soviets and Americans, since there was no way to survive if the alliance persisted.

So they wait for the long-delayed formal Soviet invasion of Manchuria and proceed to largely abandon the territory, with the best units of the Kwantung army withdrawn to the Home Islands and fortified along the Korean mountains. On the US side, Overlord was projected to have casualties in excess of half a million. The Japanese knew this, and put an offer of essentially conditional surrender to the Americans to avoid the monstrous losses in men and materiel, and gain a relatively intact regional ally along with a foothold in the Korean peninsula.

The nukes are mostly set dressing, a convenient moralising narrative (whichever moral framing you prefer) for what was actually a cynical horse trade between the Japanese government, which largely survived the war intact and continued to run the country as a war economy for decades, and a US starting to actually feel the bite of the European War.

posts.com:
Bought one to use as edc/work knife. Wanted a solid OTF because I got tired of flippers having the screws loosening up, mainly the clip, and then needing submicro allen keys or torx to tighten them up. Loctite didnt help for long either. Shit brands and good brands. Buck to Kershaw to Benchmade. All had this problem. Justified the extreme price on a microtech by saying if it costs this much it has to be durable. hasnt let me down yet. As it stands 4mo into using it daily around the farm my only complaint where it falls short of flippers is the action gets bugged up and I need to douse it in blaster/kroil/wd and hit it with the air compressor but it works great after. Tried using full synth 0-20 oil for that and it was fine while in temps at 50F and up but once it started getting below freezing during the day the oil was too thick and the action would stick in both directions.
>>56450987
My buddy laid his bike down on the interstate with one in his front pocket. Thing was beat to fuck but didnt open. Outside it trashed but it still functions perfectly. Ive given my knife to someone who needed to use it for a second and they get confused as to why its so stiff to open. Call em garbage knives but they have some shit figured out.

>>56453335
>Don't even care if I don't get to shoot it desu
Hand on heart, Anon, buy a fucking metal Airsoft or BB-firing replica. It will save you hundreds of dollars and it'll still feel satisfying to heft. Plus full-auto airguns are still legal.

If you're poor as fuck and want one "do it all" gun, get a pump shotgun. It'll cost you about $200-500 to get ammo, accessories including a light, a side-saddle, and a hundred rounds or so of practice ammo and buckshot. It's good enough for hunting, it's better than a pistol for home defense, and they're still fun to shoot at the range.

If you're specifically worried about learning to shoot and getting better at it, buy a low-to-mid-range AR instead. This will cost around $5-700. Many states ban hunting with .223/5.56 ammunition, however, or regulate magazine size and various rifle features.

If all you want is that Soviet Drip, then buy an SKS and (optionally) an aftermarket folding stock and/or a 30-round mag. The SKS has the advantage of being legal in almost every state because it's not spooky, it fires the same round as the AK-47 (which is legal for hunting in all but a couple of states that ban rifle hunting outright), and it's cheaper than most old AKs at this point.

If you're looking for self-defense, then buy a cheap 9mm pistol (whatever feels good in your hand, there are a bunch of options in the $250-500 range, most hovering around $350-400), a couple spare magazines, and about 500 rounds of ammo.

Optionally, for any of the above, go find a cheap .22LR rifle. Bolt, lever, pump, semi-auto, it really doesn't matter. It's the easiest and cheapest way to learn to shoot.

It goes beyond just worrying about our skins. I mean, a couple of my friends, mostly women, were scared, but the prevailing emotion was just hatred for Russia and a drive to help Ukrainians I have never seen in my life.

We're not talking big government help. I work in IT, usually far removed from such issues, but suddenly everyone got somehow involved in helping and was actively recruiting others. At work we were looking for jobs we could give to Ukrainians. My richer friends were renting apartments free of charge, or letting Ukrainians crash on their couches. Some of my experiences:
>A couple of my friends on their own reached out to a Ukrainian factory making sweets, organized a driver willing to go there and bring the goods, and were calling everyone if they want to buy some sweets to keep the factory afloat.
>A guy who had a small taxi company started doing fares for free. He and his drivers would take Ukrainian men, drive them to the border, and bring women and children back to Warsaw.
>Google has a policy where they double charity donations. My friends who work there contacted everyone in our group to donate money though Google "semi-legally" to double the impact. What's more, my friends themselves would add 50% to whatever anyone donated. And people were donating BIG, I'm talking over 1k$ per person, which is a lot for Poles.
>Even my building administration hired a Ukrainian girl to help with the cleaning.

I have never seen such a grassroots movement in my life.

I have a lot of recurrent dreams that I cycle through, but one nightmare among them is a group of criminals who stalk and hunt my family. They aren’t typical gangbangers, but rather are white middle-aged psychopaths (with a cold woman as a leader) — think like Home Alone franchise villains but on steroids. They always have the most sinister expressions on their faces too: We go from town to town evading them, but they always find us eventually. The only difference is that instead of setting McCallister booby traps, I go straight to rifles and shotguns with the intent to kill. Sometimes I successfully defend my neighborhood / dwelling against them, other times the dream ends before I am killed, and the other outcomes vary. My tactics are almost always stealth / ambush rather than head-on engagements, though. ,

What most creeps me out is their unexplainable, persistent campaign against me / us. It’s some Michael Myers shit. I imagine that the nightmare is a manifestation of my greatest fear in life — losing or not being able to protect my family against a threat.

posts.com: Before I had experience with guns I used to have dreams all the fucking time as a teen where whenever I would use a gun I would be unable to pull the trigger or load it. Like the trigger would be completely stiff or the magazine would just dematerialize or be empty, etc. Now as an adult, even in my worst nightmares I'm always able to fire my gun. I'm able to reload a shotgun/rifle without dropping the shell and all my guns fire when I pull the trigger. Though, although the gun will fire in all of my dreams, in some nightmares the creature or person be unaffected by the shot and I'll get killed. I swear, I've had some of the worst fucking nightmares since I was a young child, as even as young as 5, I remember vividly having nightmares about these creatures I called "the flying men". They ended up looking pretty much exactly like the Ringwraiths in LotR, so you can imagine my surprise when I saw that movie on release at age 12 and nearly had a heart attack seeing those creatures for the first time, as they would always kill me in horrific ways, or kill my parents, or wear my parents skin and kill me. God I still remember the first dream I had when I blasted one in the fucking face with a shotgun after years of actually owning and practicing with one and thankfully I haven't dreamt of them since.

We may get to a point where directed light weapons are used so frequently that the battlefield is going to be a nightmare of flying beams splitting and diffracting off of surfaces (including vehicle armour which may become shiny to deflect beams) so at the very least I think in future infantry will have to have a full visor of tinted glass, possibly even an enclosed VR headspace just so they don't instantly go fucking blind the moment they step onto the battlefield.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56457632
Currently? No. Too much weight, not enough ventilation, limits visibility if you're going with the budget option of some mind of clear polymer eye protection, prohibitively expensive if going with the camera and screen based vision system and an enclosed front (or more likely an armored visor with the screens on it that can be lifted up with clear polymer eyepieces underneath as backup). Latter option also has issues with powering the things for extended periods and the necessity to charge them.
In the future? Yeah I see it happening. As a civilization we'll likely become more adverse to casualties and manufacturing and resource extraction will develop to the point where they're desirable and viable. The heat/ventilation problem can be taken care of with intake fans and maybe even cooling/heating devices using the same principles as heat exchangers in the home. Would need to be integrated into some kind of suit so as to have enough room for the heat exchanger unit though, and you'd need a power source. Also some kind of support for the helmet's weight, be it passive with springs and whatnot or active a la power armor. There will probably be some transitionary pieces but I don't see full head protection for the common soldier until we get to that point. At which point, one would have to ask themselves if the common footsoldier would still be around performing the current role they do, or if we'll see an increasingly unmanned battlefield.

>>56453551
Doubles have several advantages over pumps or semis.
-there's no space wasted by the bolt, so the whole gun can be shorter for the same length barrel, or you can have a longer barrel for the same overall length of gun
-you can have two different chokes in the gun at the same time, so depending on what shot presents itself you can choose which barrel to fire.
-as above, but you can load different types of shells, so if you're out innawoods but you're not sure what game you may encounter, you can have birdshot in one barrel and buckshot or a slug in the other.
-their ergonomics are superior
Really their only disadvantage is capacity, but even that isn't very important. If you're hunting or you're shooting clays the extra capacity is pointless. The extra capacity certainly is relevant for defense use, but if you want a fighting weapon then why are you cucking yourself with a shotgun in the first place?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56452282
>Just be aware that some nicer scopes have an adjustment not only for the zoom (rear) but it may also have an adjustment for distance in yards
>few scopes have that unless you're shooting longer distance
Pretty much all modern scopes have parallax correction (except LPVOs) no matter if it's a cheap scope, it works kind of like a focus on a camera. It sounds like you're new to using optics so FYI you shouldn't set the parallax according to the distance markings. You start with the parallax at the longest distance (infinity) and carefully adjust till the reticle and target are both in focus as much as they can be. Also, you need to set the diopter (it's on the eyepiece of the scope) to your eye. To do so, simply point it at something with a uniform color and lack of features, like a wall, then focus your eye on the reticle and adjust the diopter till the reticle is in focus. Try to keep your focus from switching to the background (wall) while adjusting the diopter.

The most adjustment my scopes have had is two turrets for zeroing, a ring to change zoom, and maybe if I'm lucky, the rear objective allows you to turn the bell and lock it to change focus; most of my scopes are a normal 3-9, again, with a fixed parallax.

Pic related is what I'm trying to describe to anon on old scopes. On modern scopes, you may have a "third" turret for yardage adjustment instead...I think? You can turn it off. It was turned off in one of the crashes. It's just that turning it off also turned off motors adjusting the trim, meaning you have to crank the trim wheel yourself with no assistance. All this with no warning to the pilots, who didn't know any of this shit.

But yeah, it was just a certification thing. Fly-by-wire itself works fine when implemented with the legitimate intention of making the plane more controllable instead of cutting certification time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436809
Superweapons are rarely a thing. Really the only real one I'd say is Nukes which did drastically alter how war is waged, and knocked Japan out of the war.

Most of the Nazi 'wunderwaffe' were born out of desperation or meth, and none of them would have worked.

I'll say though the American 'Superfortress Bombers' were pretty close being able to deliver massive payloads over vast distances, but you still can't bomb a country out of a war (save for nukes).

But I mean look at the other major advances of the World Wars, Submarines, Tanks, Planes, Chemical Weapons, Machine Guns. None of them won the war. Russia fell to Revolution. The Central Powers were starved out of the war. It wasn't one weapon that did it.

I will say though the Ottomans had a couple of aces up their sleeve that they owe their success to.
-A proffessional army, they weren't that unique in this regard but they were early adopters compared to most of their neighbors, and levies and knights can't compare.
-Coffee, imported from africa and then the Middle East, it allows your soldiers to stay awake during marches and sieges, as well as good for boosting morale, arguable the only real combat drug that exists.
-Vaccines, the islamic world better preserved knowledge of the Classical Age, and would rub all the kids of the village against the sick one to innoculate them, other times they'd cut off a bit of the sick kids skin and sew it underneath again for innoculation. The Ottomans did this likewise meaning that their population growth was way higher than the average for Europe, meaning the nation bounced back after major battles way faster than European Nations thought possible.
-Cannons, this wasn't an edge they had for long as the Mongols helped introduce gunpowder to the rest of Europe and the Middle East, but one of the prominent early use of Cannons was in the Seige of Constantinople that was vital to breaking their legendary defenses.

>I don't think I have anything that won't glow.
it is surprising what will and what will not, but generally anything with stretch/waterproof will reflect light. rubber and plastic hardware will absorb light (show up as black). nir treated or berry compliant gear and clothes will reflect the amount of light appropriate for their daytime color (ie is still useful for camo in the dark) using unscented plain chapstick or camo face paint can dull reflective surfaces such as watches or baeofeng screens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't understand why everyone shits on the Automatic Rifleman concept. The idea of a GPMG made sense back in the day because the surrounding infantry would have large caliber rifles with little ammo, i.e. bolt actions or battle rifles with five magazines total.
Having something that can lay down lots of accurate suppressing fire while being one-man portable and operated made sense in that context.
However, even then it had issues.
>Belt-feds require belts to work
Sure you can have ammo commonality with the infantry rifle, but if your belt is disintegrating or lost, it means jack shit.
>Increased weight and complexity
Belt feds require significantly more maintenance and training to effectively use, plus the guy that carries it is gonna be miserable and exhausted.
The large size of the belt-feds make them easy to spot and target by opposing infantry as well, and if the only guy who knows how to use it properly is no longer able to, congratulations, you no longer have a machine gun.
Then you move on to the adoption of 5.5-ish mm assault rifles, guns thst offer signifcantly greater hit probability and ammunition carrying capacity than ever before.
Then the belt fed makes even less sense for infantry, as even in 5.56, it's big, heavy, complicated, and still easily targeted, while having far less penetrating power.
A heavy barreled assault rifle equipped with a bipod makes a lot of sense as a SAW, since:
>It's 99% the same as a regular rifle, anybody can effectively use it
>True ammo commonality, uses magazines
>If properly designed (like the USMC M27), it can achieve the same overall round count as a belt-fed while being significantly lighter, cheaper, easier to use and maintenance, and simpler to train
>It looks almost identical to any other rifle, can't be easily identified and shot
>Far more reliable due to being less complicated overall
Obviously a GPMG still makes sense for emplaced positions and Tanks, but a automatic rifle is better for mobile infantry.

posts.com:
Kamikazes did have higher hit rates than conventional attacks by the end of the war, but that is more indicative of how poorly the Japanese were doing and not proof suicide attacks were a good idea. It ignores the core problem that the Japanese Naval Air Service failed to keep up on technology and training. Rather than using experience pilots to train new ones, they were kept in their tightly knit units and engagements like Midway wiped them out. Lesser-skilled pilots were put in aircraft which were becoming less-effective.
And by the war's end, making it through the American defenses to even get a chance to attack a ship was not easy. Kamikaze tactics only make sense when you admit you've fallen so far behind that you can't train your pilots or provide them competitive aircraft.

>>56440576
One of the irony's of WW2. Japan has a collectivist culture, but by refusing to really acknowledge air-aces, their aces stayed in the field where they would get shot down. America has an individualist culture, meaning aces were quickly recognized by their military and then pulled back to train new recruits resulting in a stronger overall air-force.
>>56443804
One of their key strenghs was a mortal weakness. Most airplanes at the time had vacuum sealed gas-tanks. The Japanese removed this to allow the Zero to be lighter and faster which was their major strength. The reason you vacuum seal tanks though is that a half-empty tank is a bomb, half full with explosives and oxygen meaning it lights up in a fireball when lit.

This is why the Zero dominated in the early stages of the war as they fought against inferior number of planes, but failed when the US managed to face them pound-for-pound.

Also after the initial kamikaze attacks the Americans learned real quick to shoot dive-bombing planes, so most kamikaze strikes after the first few initial ones were quickly shot down before reaching their targets- ie it stopped being an effective tactic real quick.

>>56444559
Different kind of vulnerable. The Zero had trouble in high-speed dives in that it was hard to handle and would lose most of its maneuverability in one. This is the case to some degree with any airplane, especially back in the days before fly-by-wire, some just had it worse than others.

>>56445539
The Japanese keeping their aces in the field was more of a doctrinal thing and because they for the most part wanted to stay in the field. I mean, do you think the Germans were a "collectivist culture", too? Because they likewise tended to keep their ace pilots in the field.

>Most airplanes at the time had vacuum sealed gas-tanks.

Actually, self-sealing tanks were very much a rarity when the A6M hit the field in 1940. (And they weren't vacuum sealed. The way they generally worked was by layering vulcanized rubber, untreated rubber and treated reinforcing fabric over each other. In case of a leak, the untreated rubber around it would soak up escaping fuel, swell up and seal the hole.)

To put it into perspective, the F4F-3 Wildcat was one of the earliest USN planes with self-sealing tanks, and only entered production around the same time the Zero had its first flight. And the inital tank design on the F4F-3 also didn't work properly. They only managed to get working ones mere days before Coral Sea.

The Zerodidn't remove anything, it just didn't have something that most planes of its generation didn't have. Later adoption proved problematic because the extra weight and reduced range would cause a lot of issues and the Japanese were hesitant to make major model changes out of fear of having to reduce production. The A5M5 model received one-shot nitrogen fire extinguishing systems for its fuel tanks instead, which just wouldn't save the remaining fuel in the tank. Late M5s and the M6 model then finally introduced full self-sealing tanks.

Again, I can only recommend watching this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ApOfbxpL4Dg&t=7092s [Remove]

>>56453850
>not enough to get the degree
No, it's not like you've punched your ticket the moment you get a BA or BSc. But it's not JUST about connections, it's also things like qualifications and recognition. A lot of employers are close minded when it comes to what institutions they recognize; they may see "Army" or "Marine" and unless they also see "officer" or at least "non-commissioned officer", then it isn't doing you many favors in a civilian job hunt. Connections are important, but they don't mean you've got a guaranteed job at {company}, either.
>Why shouldn't I just stay in the military?
Depends on how you've done with the military. There's good benefits and excellent career progression. That I won't deny. The military has very clear paths within its structure. However, the civilian side has far more opportunity, if you're able to see it. All this depends entirely on what you, Anon, are good at; what skills can you effectively bring to the table, both soft skills and technical? What are you interested in doing in life?

350F here. Hit the button on medboarding. Submitted more claims than I realized I actually had. 9.5 years AD and should be 10 years RES by the time this all finals out next spring. Pretty much squared away for retirement as a CW4 once I can actually collect. Current plan is to keep doing my gg14 job until all of this is done, then i think I might switch to remote work as something gs9-12 and move the wife and kids out to our property. House should be done getting built in may, but I am going to hold off on any major life changes until the medboard is done.

Anyhow, probably wont post on here anymore. So good luck anons, and its been great chatting with some of the regulars over the years.

Also, last update on clearances: reinvestigations no longer exist for all branches (army finally hit the button last week). Everyone regardless of clearance type will now be required to update a sf86 every 5 years, while simultaneously being enrolled in Continuous Vetting system where your info is scanned constantly against law enforcement, HR, and financial systems for shit you need to report such as crimes, bankruptcies, collections debt, demotions, art 15s, etc. It behooves you to self report this shit when it happens so the clearance folks dont panic and make a fuss over potentially minor issues that you could get your clearanced suspended for.

And one last reminder if you are brand new and even considering joining the military, read Once an Eagle by Anton Myrer before you decide to pursue this path. Ignore the online reviews, I swear those people never actually read the book or they skimmed it to write reviews/book reports without grasping the full picture. The "staff officer bad/field officer good" theme that all the reviewers keep pushing is false. If they actually read it they wouldnt have come to that conclusion.

/personal blog. Signing off.

They probably went beyond giant explosions and learned ways to contain, direct and utilize this enormous energy to power new types of devices. Devices that open perspectives incompatible with current world order. There's ton of miraculous physics articles where the only shortcoming is "would require stellar amounts of power to do". As a minimum i bet they're a cheap and feasible way to make stuff that currently takes years and trillions. Like antimatter. If an accelerator can make few, i'm certain a bomb in correct configuration could dump large part of its energy into a ball of pocket-able havoc.

And keeping with the habits of humanity, it will probably kept away until enough old farts die. Or if they develop the new stuff out so well they can stomp anyone who just figured it out.

posts.com:
Most people allocate roughly half their budget to the gun and half to the glass. With that in mind, for the noob who wants to get into precision rifle shooting

>under $500
Savage Axis, Ruger American (these often come with dogshit $40 scopes on them in a package, you'll likely want to immediately replace the scope and rings)
>under $1000
Tikka T3X, Bergara B14

I'd recommend starting with the T3X or B14. The T3X Lite is a good rifle for hunting, while the T3X CTR and B14 HMR are really heavy and more aimed at bench shooting. Don't cheap out on the glass. Also, don't be afraid of hearing that 6.5 Creed burns out barrels by 1200-1500 rounds, the barrels in these rifles are pretty easy to swap out.

When there is the PTR C93.

The successor of the STG44 is the STG45.

The STG45 became later the G3.

The HK53 is the intermediate cartridge version of the G3.

And the HK93 is the semi-auto version of the HK53.

The PTR C93 is the clone version of the Hk93.

All you have to do is buy the PTR C93. Change all the plastic parts to stamped metal parts.
And you have a cloned STG44 that is much less prone to failure.
