Previous >>56355642
nobody made a new thread edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>56442373
They don't. PVS-7s use MX10130 format tubes while PVS-14s (And almost everything else these days) use MX11769 or MX10160 tubes. (With 11769 and 10160 tubes being essentially interchangeable and differing only in that the 11769 has a "pigtail" ribbon cable for manual gain control.)

A 1997 tube won't have the performance of a modern tube. You might be able to sell it at a profit, but not $2k.

It's not a bad buy. The 1990's ITT Mariners are $650 and while /nvg/ doesn't like PVS-7s, a -7 is a hell of a lot more useful tactically than an ITT Mariner.

There is one Chinese monocular housing with an inverter if you really want to convert it to a monocular. I would probably leave it as is and use it.

posts.com:
>>56440057
With thermal always start by deciding what optical magnification you want. Then get the highest resolution sensor you can afford with that optical mag.

If your friend wants 1x hand held on a budget one of the best deals is the "GOYOJO Thermal Monocular - Night Vision Imaging 384x288" on Amazon. It's a 1x mag 384 core for $550.

I have the AGM TM10-256 which is a 1x mag 256 core. I really like it, though it's the same price as the GOYOJO. One advantage though is that AGM is a U.S. based company with good tech support. But keep in mind all of these devices are made in China any way.

>>56452876
NTA. While no product is perfect for 100% of everyone, the 4D setup is significantly thicker than factory padding and can put you in a spot where a size up on a helmet would have been more appropriate for you with its use. The goal should be to have uniform pressure everywhere the padding touches not just a softer foam in places you are getting hot spots.
IMO start setup from scratch again and dont be afraid to mix and match the 4D with your factory stuff to get that even fit. As long as you get a balanced pressure with the brim ~0.5-0.75" above your brow and side rails parallel to the ground, a G24 should work for the vast majority of people unless its with something like an RNVG without the dovetail extension.

For NV placement, brim to brow is really the first measurement to hit. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56454859
>>56455017
>>56455552
I have a GP tube with no manual gain so it's always at max gain/brightness. I actually need the purple filter to make the tube comfortable to use, otherwise it can be painfully bright and eye fatigue is a problem. Any time I've compared filter/no filter I've always been able to see just as much with the filter, even in the darkest conditions. It actually seems to help in dark conditions by reducing apparent scintillation and increasing contrast. A big part of this is because sans filter my pupil is just dialing down more in response to the bright screen.

If you have manual gain and are always running at max because of the filter, you are technically reducing the life of your tube. So it's true that there is no free lunch. Still, for an anon on a budget, GP + filter works pretty damn well.

>Among other weapons, I had an extraordinary rifle that carried a half-pound percussion shell—this instrument of torture to the hunter was not sufficiently heavy for the weight of the projectile; it only weighed twenty pounds: thus, with a charge of ten drachms [270 grains] of powder, behind a half-pound shell, the recoil was so terrific, that I spun around like a weathercock in a hurricane. I really dreaded my own rifle, although I had been accustomed to heavy charges of powder, and severe recoil for some years. None of my men could fire it, and it was looked upon with a species of awe, and it was named "Jenna-El-Mootfah" (Child of a Cannon) by the Arabs, which being far too long a name for practice, I christened it the "Baby;" and the scream of this "Baby" loaded with a half-pound shell was always fatal. It was far too severe, and I very seldom fired it, but it is a curious fact, that I never fired a shot with that rifle without bagging: the entire practice, during several years, was confined to about twenty shots. I was afraid to use it; but now and then it was absolutely necessary that it should be cleaned, after months of staying loaded. On such occasions my men had the gratification of firing it, and the explosion was always accompanied by two men falling on their backs (one having propped up the shooter), and the "Baby" flying some yards behind them. This rifle was made by Holland & Holland, of Bond Street, and I could highly recommend it for the Goliath of Gath, but not for the men of A.D. 1866.
>Sir Samuel White Baker, The Albert N'Yanza, Great Basin Of The Nile

>And a protective housing is probs overkill. Would be more likely to just be a special lens that blocks out radiation of specific wavelengths. Some kind of doped ceramic lens maybe.
Leaded glass lens or screw on "filter" may work, at least if the radiation is going directly towards the camera, though I have to wonder how thick that would have to be to tone down such a large amount of radiation. Tangent, but related: CRT TVs put out a small amount of radiation; some time in the 40s or 50s IIRC some cheap TVs were putting out a little too much so the government (US) ended up regulating how much radiation they can put out and started requiring companies to just make the front of the picture tubes out of leaded glass. It blocks at least some of the radiation. And no, you're not getting eye or brain cancer from a CRT; even at sitting-at-desk distances, it gives roughly the same radiation as the sun itself. Or was it a third the radiation you get from standing in the sun? I forget.
>Didn't know radiation affected old times film though, cool info.

I think sapphire lenses block out some radiation. I know our chromatography machine has doped sapphire glass lenses for when we throw radioactive stuff in it. Apparently they have pretty good refraction and absorption indexes too. Expensive as fuck though, and some kinds of radiation can apparantly cause the lens to be "polluted" by causing lens material to turn into isotopes that decay into contaminants. Cool about CRT's, didn't know that. I know leaded glass has a lot of neat properties, great optics too, shame it got turned into a health-care and dropped out of favour as drinking glass material. It's only really an issue if you store high proof alcohol long-term in decanters. Drinking glasses emptied in 1 sitting leech next to no lead into the contents.

Just offhandedly a /k/ subject topic; do anyone know if gun optics are from any particular type of glass? I'm not sure what kind is used for lenses in general, much less scopes or holosights.

I at least try to save some of the nicer ones that are being thrown out when I see them, usually the higher end models or Sonys.
>I know leaded glass has a lot of neat properties, great optics too, shame it got turned into a health-care and dropped out of favour as drinking glass material. It's only really an issue if you store high proof alcohol long-term in decanters. Drinking glasses emptied in 1 sitting leech next to no lead into the contents.
I wonder if something similar happens in uranium glass. Could alcohol "dissolve" uranium or pull it out of the glass's surface? Either way, I guess it's a good thing I don't drink alcohol out of any cup out of the ordinary, and rarely. Mostly used for cooking rather than drinking.
Note: Uranium glass only glows like this under blacklight, it glows at its best when in a dim or dark room, and this isn't my photo

>>56448403
Threads like these inspired to develop a whole tiered system, not just for firearms, but all sorts of weapon and gear related training for my kids.
It starts with water/ nerf guns, airsoft guns, then airguns, then firearms, then bows, then muzzleloaders, then totally-not-explosives, but it's not as simple as a red rider then an ar15. each type of weapon is sequentialized based on single shot rifles, then revolvers, then precision rifles, then semi autos, then full retard and the previous tier gets an "upgrade" in sophisticated operation while the new type of weapon starts from single shots. That way, kids hone multiple different skills with multiple different weapons that add to each other type of weapon's usage.
For gear and bushcraft, it starts with just simple camping, martial arts, and hunting, but builds up to earning trade certs, air/land/ and seacraft licenses, open water diving, building their own log cabin and garden in the woods, etc among MANY other skills.
Basically, by oversaturating the opportunities for my kids to learn essential survival and technical skills, they'll have a good foundation and familiarity in all aspects and some things will be bound to stick more than others that they'll each specialize according to their interests by adulthood and like weapons, each progressive tier and skill will only add to work ethic and adaptability of learning and mastering future skills

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My brother & I consulted & agreed upon certain firearms Rules when our first kids were born. We figured there would be enough interaction that we should standardize on 'most things.' We also have similar (not identical) experiences growing up, me being the elder by 3 years & a much more enthusiastic firearms & weapons guy than he is. What we wanted to avoid was conflicting training, at least until they were all old enough to understand that people can have differences, and that doesn't mean anyone is necessarily wrong.

I became the primary (not exclusive) instructor, which also included their friends when it was appropriate. By accident, I ended up being the primary instructor for about 8 different families beyond me & my brother.

Trigger & muzzle discipline began at age 5, even a bit earlier with any airborne object (such as rubber bands, rubber band guns, paper airplanes, etc.). The fragility of the eyeball is emphasized, and then expanded upon for other injuries. Everyone gets that eyes hurt when damaged & are important.

Access to any firearm is severely restricted, and begins with air rifles (after water pistols & nerf guns & such). Anyone violating basic rules gets special training. It's not pleasant but not designed as punishment either. Our kids all fired their first .22 (bolt action) around age 7. When they met certain goals for behavior & marksmanship, they were graduated to .410, .22 WMR, and eventually revolvers in .22 and .38 Spl. During the Summers, about 3 times a month until they were about 10-11 (~20 times/year).

By age 12 they were shooting almost everything I have under .30-06 and .357 mag. By 13-ish, they were shooting everything including 12 ga. This was when I allowed them to shoot semi-auto in .22 rifle and 9mm handgun.

Nobody (that I know of) ever picked up a weapon without checking if it's loaded, or flagged anyone with the muzzle (after about age 8). Trigger discipline has been so good they've caught me out more than I've caught them.

>>56450941
Fun fact. This is actually Scorpion W1 (current OCPs are Scorpion W2). This pattern was specifically made for the Army right before 9/11.

It isn't clear why they never adopted the pattern, but Crye took the work they did here and developed Multicam from it. Scorpion (OCP) actually precedes Multicam.

2014 camo trials, Crye won the competition and was set to provide the army with Multicam (OEF-CP), Multicam Arid, and a newly made Multicam woodland; beating Kryptek, Brookwood, and Guy Cramer's Hyperstealth (dba ADS inc)

DOD didn't want to pay licensing fees, and Congress specifically banned any branch from adopting a new pattern unless all other branches also adopted it at the same time. Army wanted multicam, and realized they still held the pattern for Scorpion, and modified it in house to produce Scorpion W2, which was adopted as OCP.

picrel is one of the few publically available pics of the 2013-2014 trials

t. autistic tranner obsessed with camo

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Why do people always give stupid bullshit like >muh prone and >muh spitzer bullet as reasons for armies picking bolt actions over levers? I can shoot prone fine with a lever gun and the 1895 winchester predates spitzer rounds (not to mention the 1886 uses spitzer rounds and has a tube mag).
The reasons I think the lever guns never were primary first world army guns are the following
1. Boomer biases thinking lever guns were weak.
Lever actions had been out for 25 years before Browning made the 1886 (35 years until the 1895 rifle) and as such, dealing with the weaker rifles made the turbo boomers at the time think the lever action system was weaker, even though the 1886 can shoot .45-70 and the 1895 can shoot .30-06 and x54r. Bolt actions are stronger actions for sure, but lever guns are capable of firing the smokeless military rounds of WWI
2. Cost.
I think this is the biggest reason. Even now look at the price of a new henry, winchester or marlin rifle vs a ruger or savage shitter that costs $300 and shoots 1 moa
3. Reliability and safety
I absolutely trust a Mauser 1898 to work in the mud and not kaboom and hurt me over a 1895. The Mauser would be more closed to the elements and mud, have more safety redundancies and would have better primary extraction to get those shitty 1910s cartridges out of the chamber than the 1895 would

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56443770
>1. Boomer biases thinking lever guns were weak.
Wrong. It's because stronger bolt actions started seeing military service as general issue rifles before lever actions with stronger mechanisms started being made, and had plenty of institutional inertia by the time John Moses Browning started designing stronger lever actions. Why waste money retraining soldiers on an completely different gun if you don't have to?

Not included in your list is cleaning (which bolt actions are significantly easier to take down for), and the issue that rate of fire difference between manual action repeaters stops mattering as much when you're dealing with large groups of soldiers rather than individuals. For an individual, lever actions do have clear advantages, but what's best for the individual isn't necessarily best for the military.

>>56443770
Bolt actions predate lever actions by about 15 years. France and Prussia had both already standardized on bolt actions by 1860 and by the 1880s Britain had as well. Lever guns were just always two steps behind. When bolt guns became repeaters, lever guns couldn't take full power cartridges. When lever guns were using tubes bolt guns had switched to box magazines. By the time they were equal in the late 1890s everyone had already adopted a bolt gun. Then they just coasted on institutional momentum until autoloaders came along.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>France using bolt actions since 1866
>Germany using bolt actions since 1866
>Switzerland using bolt actions since 1869
>Italy using bolt actions since 1870
>Russia using bolt actions since 1870
>Austria using bolt actions since 1886
>Britain using bolt actions since 1888
>America using a bolt action since 1892
By the time a smokeless, military loading lever action came out, all the major nations had already set in stone to training and equipping guns using the bolt action pattern. There wasn't any good advantage to the lever action rifle that would justify changing what they were already used to.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56444577
You're a troll, or a retard, or a nogunz.

A bore snake is a fantastic addition to your cleaning kit, but it doesn't replace anything. Best use I've found for it is to stand in for running patch after patch through a barrel to chase residue.

My personal cleaning routine for barrels goes like this :
- run a solvent soaked patch down the barrel, back and forth a bit; pretty much saturate the inside of the barrel with solvent. Patch usually comes out near black.
- run an appropriately sized bronze brush down the barrel twice to dislodge anything that might be stubborn
- pull the bore snake through the barrel, twice, to pick up solvent residue and everything else
- lightly oil a patch with CLP and run it down the barrel on the end of a spear point jag of appropriate diameter, usually comes out clean or close enough to clean. If it isn't clean, repeat the whole process. The patch should have just enough CLP on it to leave a light film to protect the inside of the barrel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56455893
"Only" one. At the time, all I really had in the way of guns was a few .22 plinkers, a single-shot 12 gauge, an ancient .32 revolver, a .357 SAA clone, and a Mosin. I was concerned about home defense in case the 2020 Great Chimpening came to my doorstep, since most of my guns were either of too small a caliber, too big to maneuver with inside, or too difficult to reload in an emergency.
Unrelated, I decided I would peruse a few guns at my LGS and see what surp they had left before the panic buyers took it all. While looking at a nice double barrel from 1903 or so, some guy burst into the store and said that there was a riot going on right down the street. I was not carrying at the time because I hadn't got my CC permit, so I took a wood-stocked Mossberg pump and decided this would do on my budget if I had to defend myself, be it home defense or having to fight my way through a horde of darkies to get there first.
In the end, the police here ended up shutting it down before it even got to the chimpout phase, so it was quiet for the rest of the year and I felt dumb for panic-buying it when I didn't need it, especially because I lost out on the double barrel I wanted and because I probably could have gotten something better for the price like an SKS or something.
After that I decided I would never let my fears get the best of me again. It certainly shouldn't happen again because I've armed myself better since then with guns I've done a fair bit of research on. If something like 2020 Floydfest does happen again, my AR should suffice. And I do still have that shotgun, so perhaps one day it's purchase will be vindicated.

>>56456555
> how do you stop it

Even if you could get subterrenes to work (and there's plenty of reasons why they're a stupid idea) then they'd have the same critical vulnerability as the tunnel boring machines used in civil engineering projects around the world: A massive, complicated and vulnerable logistics chain. All the tunnel supports, spoil removal, power, cooling, ventilation, communication and navigation needs of the machine have to be supported from the surface. This results in a large encampment at the tunnel entrance that makes an easy target to identify and strike.

>I will remember that around the time there were Mercedes’ with 3 million km driving around in Africa.
This. In 1992 my dad bought a Mercedes E-320. In 2005 it became my first car. In 2007 I took it off to college, a 16 hour drive from home. It fucking mogged the open road. In 2014, after college, I drove it to work every day until I saved up enough to buy a car in 2016. It had ~380 000 miles on the clock when I traded it in. For 25 years it ran like a fucking bomb. Zero major problems. None. In the 10 years I had it the only issue was that the aircon fan behind the dash had a bad bearing and some of the seals on the joints had to be replaced. Thats it. Obvi the seats were trashed. To this day I regret not holding onto it for another two years just to see her push over the last big 400K milestone.

Without doubt the best car I have ever had in my life.

Depends entirely on what I'm shooting for and at. If I'm shooting elk I shoot the 208 ELDM and I aim for 2820. >>56454039
Medfag here.

What Professor calculus is describing here is actually a real drug, although it does not have permanent effects. It's called Disulfiram aka antabuse, they used to use it more commonly to train alcoholics to avoid alcohol. Basically alcohol is first turned into an aldehyde by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, and the aldehydes cause many of the unpleasant symptoms associated with being drunk like nausea, vomiting, and flushing. However it is quickly converted into a secondary metabolite by the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase so you don't experience those symptoms unless you drink excessively and the enzyme gets saturated.

Disulfiram inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing the person to build up aldehydes and causing intense symptoms as soon as any amount of alcohol is consumed. Also the antibiotic metronidazole, commonly given for bacterial vaginal infections and UTIs, has this feature as a side effect.

The more you know

My understanding of the problem with antimatter is that it doesn't exactly explode. Because it annihilates and converts into energy, the byproducts don't expand in the form of matter, so you don't really get the kinetic energy that comes from a proper explosion. Sure, you could bathe an area in radiation, and you can superheat the air causing that to expand, but it won't expand as much as explosion byproducts would and typically what you want is to deliver kinetic energy on the target.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56447019
Yeah. What many people hear from matter-animatter reactions is "WOW LOTS OF ENERGY", when the reality is that matter is a kidn of field (as in, like a magnetic field) that gives mass its substance, and antimatter is just the same field but a trough instead of a wave. So the two cancel each other out just like two opposing equal waves colliding cancel each other out, and while energy is created from the reaction there is no boom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56442454
>You're still not going to be engaging tanks with it
Engaging tanks with an autocannon is generally kind of flawed anyway. The only time you really should be doing it is if you are to the side or behind them, in which case the 60mm possesses basically the same capacity as previous calibers.
>The only advantage I could see is it having more explosive mass, but is that worth the trade off in fire rate?
Unironically probably. For anti-infantry use and light buildings the difference becomes pretty drastic. The increasing caliber of tank cannons during WWII was largely responsible for the decline in effectiveness of anti-tank guns.
It went from 37mm cannons that had about as much explosive filler as a weak hand grenades to >75mm shells that might have more than ten times as much filler.
You can imagine the margin of error for missing an anti-tank gun becomes much larger when you're raining down small artillery shells vs throwing small grenades at an exposed crew. The same logic applies to ATGM crews and light buildings.
So you basically get an autocannon that has a sweet spot where its increased effectiveness per round offsets the decrease in ammunition capacity without treading into the area of very large autocannons (think ~75mm+) that will have a severely decreased ammunition capacity relative to the effectiveness per round

Yeah but right now it seems like 40mm is the king of autocannons. >>56456022
To remove a ball that is stuck between the cylinder and the barrel of a Remington model 1858 cap and ball revolver, you will need to follow these steps:

Make sure that the revolver is unloaded and that there are no caps on the nipples.

Open the cylinder by pulling the loading lever down and rotating the cylinder out of the frame.

Inspect the ball and try to determine the cause of the jam. If the ball is not seated properly in the chamber, it may be possible to push it back into place with a wooden dowel or a cleaning rod.

If the ball is stuck because it is too large for the chamber, you may be able to remove it by gently tapping it with a wooden dowel or a cleaning rod. Be careful not to damage the cylinder or the barrel.

If the ball cannot be removed by tapping it, you may need to use a ball puller. This is a tool that consists of a rod with a hook on the end that is used to grab the ball and pull it out of the barrel.

If the ball is still stuck after trying these methods, you may need to disassemble the revolver and remove the barrel in order to access the stuck ball. This should be done by a qualified gunsmith.

It is important to note that tampering with a firearm can be dangerous and should only be done by someone who is familiar with the proper safety procedures and has the necessary tools and knowledge. If you are not comfortable attempting to remove a stuck ball from your revolver, it is recommended that you seek the help of a qualified gunsmith.
